title: 111_hr6246
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rural Energy Communities Development Act of 2010". It establishes the Rural Energy Communities Loan Program. The Secretary of Agriculture may make loans to eligible communities for essential community facilities for any purpose described in subsection (c). An eligible community is a city, town, or incorporated area with a population of less than 20,000 individuals and has experienced net job growth in the energy sector of not less than 20 percent from January 1999 through December 2009. An eligible community can use loan funds for essential facilities like water conservation, drainage improvements, transportation, and affordable housing. Funds can also be used for land acquisition, municipal staff, and updates to community plans. To receive a loan, the community must submit an application to the Secretary of Agriculture. An eligible community must submit an application to the Secretary of Agriculture with details of projects for loan fund usage, a certification for loan purpose, and proof of financial capacity to repay the loan, including evidence of dedicated energy tax revenue. The community must provide documentation of expected funds and non-Federal supplemental funds for essential facilities to be funded with loan amounts. Priority is given to applicants with completed plans or studies identifying infrastructure needs. Loan amounts received under this section must address specific infrastructure needs or demonstrate regional cooperation with adjacent jurisdictions. The principal amount of any loan may not exceed $20,000,000 or 80% of the energy tax revenue expected by the applicant. Interest rates on loans are subject to the provisions of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act. The Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act sets terms for loan repayment not exceeding 15 years. Forgiveness of up to 50% of the remaining loan balance is possible under certain circumstances. Annual reports are required until the loan is repaid. The Secretary of Agriculture must submit a report detailing the progress of projects financed with loan funds. $75 million is authorized for loans in fiscal years 2011 and 2012. The maximum loan commitment allowed is $400 million, and no loans can be made after September 30, 2012. SEC. 3. WAIVER OF INCOME MAXIMUMS FOR SELECTED USDA RURAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS. For fiscal years 2011 through 2016, income limitations for obtaining loans under section 502 of the Housing Act of 1949 are waived for eligible community residents. Additionally, the eligibility requirement for borrowers under section 502(h)(3) does not apply. Organizations or tribes receiving loans under section 524 of the same Act must also waive income limitations related to housing occupancy on building sites. For loans under section 538 of the Housing Act of 1949, income limitations related to housing occupancy in eligible communities must be waived.
